senses.de: The sensation realized by the tongue when it experiences food or drink.
senses.ex: I love the taste of strawberries.

Tips.title: Sensory Experience
Tips.description: Use 'taste' to describe the sensory experience involving your tongue and sense of smell.
Tips.example: The taste of garlic lingers in my mouth.

Tips.title: Subjective Perception
Tips.description: 'Taste' can be subjective, so what tastes good to one person may not to another.
Tips.example: I dislike the taste of cilantro, but my friend loves it.

Tips.title: Describing Flavors
Tips.description: Combine 'taste' with adjectives to describe specific flavors, such as 'sweet' or 'sour'.
Tips.example: The sweet taste of ripe mangoes is delightful.

senses.de: A person's preference or liking for something.
senses.ex: Everyone has their own taste in music.

Tips.title: Personal Likes
Tips.description: Use 'taste' when talking about preferences, especially in creative or cultural contexts.
Tips.example: Our tastes in books are quite different.

Tips.title: Cultural Differences
Tips.description: 'Taste' often reflects cultural influences, informing preferences in food, art, and more.
Tips.example: His taste in clothing is influenced by his culture.

senses.de: To experience or perceive the flavor of something by putting it in your mouth.
senses.ex: I tasted the soup and it was delicious.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Use 'taste' metaphorically to describe a brief experience of something larger.
Tips.example: She got a taste of acting in school plays and pursued it as a career.

Tips.title: Hint of Experience
Tips.description: A 'taste' can be a small hint that introduces you to a new situation or environment.
Tips.example: Traveling gives you a taste of different cultures.

senses.de: A small amount of experience of something which gives you an idea of what it's like.
senses.ex: I've had a taste of the superstar lifestyle and I can see why people get addicted.

senses.de: To have a slight flavor of something, often something unwelcome.
senses.ex: The water tastes a little of chlorine.

Tips.title: Subtle Presence
Tips.description: 'Taste' describes when a flavor is not strong but noticeably present.
Tips.example: There's a taste of mint in this tea.

senses.de: A person's ability to recognize and appreciate what is beautiful, good, or well done.
senses.ex: She has excellent taste in art.

Tips.title: Judgment of Quality
Tips.description: 'Taste' can refer to the ability to appreciate quality and beauty in various domains.
Tips.example: Architects are admired for their taste in design.

Tips.title: Subjective Assessment
Tips.description: 'Taste' involves personal assessment and can differ greatly between individuals.
Tips.example: He has quite unique taste in art.

Flavour.wordDefinition:
Flavor refers to the distinctive quality that a food or drink has, often related to its ingredients and seasoning. Taste refers to the way something feels in the mouth, including sweet, salty, sour, bitter, and umami.

So, flavor is a more general term, while taste refers specifically to the different sensations on the tongue. When you talk about the overall deliciousness of something, you might use the word flavor.

Gusto.wordDefinition:
Gusto refers to the enjoyment or enthusiasm with which something is done or experienced, while taste refers to the sense of flavor or preference for certain foods or things.

For example, if you say "I ate the pizza with gusto," you mean you ate it with a lot of enthusiasm or enjoyment. If you say "I don't have a taste for spicy food," you mean you don't prefer or like spicy food.

Gusto is applicable in situations where you want to express enthusiasm, enjoyment or zest in doing something or experiencing something, while taste is more applicable when expressing your personal preference for something or the way something tastes.

Palate.wordDefinition:
Palate refers to the physical part of your mouth that can distinguish between different flavors and textures.

Palate refers to the physical ability to taste, while taste refers to personal preference for certain flavors.

Relish.wordDefinition:
Relish means to enjoy or take pleasure in something, particularly food or an experience. It implies a sense of excitement or enthusiasm.

For example, you might say that you relish the opportunity to try new foods or that you relish spending time with your friends.

Relish relates to how much pleasure or excitement you feel when experiencing something, while taste is purely focused on the flavor sensations you experience when eating or drinking.

Save.wordDefinition:
Save means to keep or preserve something for future use or to prevent harm, while taste means to sense or experience the flavor of something.

For example, you save money in a bank account so you can use it later or save leftovers in the fridge to eat later.

Save is applicable when wanting to hold onto something for the future, while taste is applicable when trying to experience a flavor.

Smack.wordDefinition:
Smack usually refers to a sudden, sharp sound, a blow, or a hit.

It can also mean a loud kiss, especially on the cheek. In slang, smack can mean a drug called heroin.

Smack is a sound or hit, while taste is a sensation or flavor. Smack is applicable in situations where there is a sudden sound or a punch, and taste is applicable when you are talking about food or trying a new product.

Tang.wordDefinition:
Tang refers to a sharp or sour flavor that is often associated with citrus fruits or certain candies. It is a more specific term than taste and can describe a specific element of a food or drink.

So, while tang refers to a specific aspect of taste, taste is a broader term that encompasses all of the various flavors and sensations that we experience when we eat or drink something.

Zest.wordDefinition:
Zest refers to the outermost layer of the rind of a citrus fruit such as lemon, lime, or orange.

In conclusion, taste refers to the actual flavor of something when consumed, while zest refers to the tangy and flavorful outermost layer of citrus fruits.

quotes.Text: I don't drink coffee. I've never had a cup of coffee in my entire life. That's something you probably don't know about me. I've hated the taste since I was a kid.
quotes.Title: American Director
quotes.Name: Steven Spielberg

quotes.Text: No man enjoys the true taste of life, but he who is ready and willing to quit it.
quotes.Title: Roman Statesman
quotes.Name: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quotes.Text: Read as you taste fruit or savor wine, or enjoy friendship, love or life.
quotes.Title: British Poet
quotes.Name: George Herbert

quotes.Text: Sometimes it's more important to be human, than to have good taste.
quotes.Title: German Poet
quotes.Name: Bertolt Brecht

quotes.Text: Bad taste is simply saying the truth before it should be said.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Mel Brooks

quotes.Text: A kiss that is never tasted, is forever and ever wasted.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Billie Holiday

quotes.Text: My characters do have some fantastic taste in men.
quotes.Title: English Actress
quotes.Name: Florence Pugh

quotes.Text: Praise us as we are tasted, allow us as we prove.
quotes.Title: English Playwright
quotes.Name: William Shakespeare

quotes.Text: Taste is so much more important than fashion.
quotes.Title: Austrian Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Hattie Carnegie

quotes.Text: There's no common taste in this world.
quotes.Title: Chinese Actor
quotes.Name: Stephen Chow
